title: Sprint Planning & Execution
description: Master two-part Sprint Planning: WHAT (select backlog items based on velocity) + HOW (team self-organizes tasks). Apply Definition of Ready and velocity-based forecasting.
objectives: Understand two-part Sprint Planning structure: WHAT (selecting backlog items) + HOW (task breakdown/estimation)
Recognize that development team self-organizes sprint backlog priorities (NOT Product Owner, NOT Scrum Master)
Apply Definition of Ready (DoR) to determine if user stories are ready for sprint inclusion
Calculate team commitment using velocity (average story points from previous sprints)
Distinguish team FORECAST (likely completion) from COMMITMENT (pledge to sprint goal)

screens.headline: Sprint 4 Planning. Morgan: 'I'll decide which tasks you work on first.' Devon: 'How many story points can we commit?' Maya wants half-defined user story. Can this sprint succeed?

items.label: Proper Sprint Planning
items.detail: Collaboration, velocity chart, DoR checklist, sprint goal

dialogue.text: Sprint Planning has TWO parts: WHAT (select stories based on velocity) and HOW (team self-organizes tasks). Get it right: achievable sprint goal. Get it wrong: sprint failure.

screens.learningHook: Learn WHO prioritizes sprint backlog tasks, WHEN a story is ready for sprint, HOW MANY points to commit, and CAN sprint backlog change mid-sprint.

screens.title: Sprint Planning Decisions
screens.instructions: Make decisions about sprint backlog ownership, Definition of Ready, velocity-based capacity, and sprint backlog flexibility.

scenarios.title: Sprint Backlog Ownership
description: Morgan (PO) says: 'I'll prioritize sprint backlog tasks—work on Online Ordering first, then Menu Update.'

questions.question: Who should prioritize task order within sprint backlog?

options.text: Product Owner (Morgan) prioritizes sprint backlog
Development Team self-organizes sprint backlog priorities
Scrum Master (Alex) assigns tasks
Stakeholders decide based on business urgency

feedback.correct: Development team self-organizes sprint backlog priorities based on technical dependencies, skills, sprint goal. PO owns PRODUCT backlog priority, but team owns SPRINT backlog self-organization.
feedback.incorrect: PO owns PRODUCT backlog priority. Team owns SPRINT backlog self-organization. Cross-functional team knows technical dependencies better than PO.

scenarios.title: Definition of Ready (DoR)
description: Maya wants to include 'Create fusion appetizer' (5 points).
Missing: acceptance criteria, ingredient list, presentation specs, dietary restrictions.
Maya: 'We can figure out details during sprint.'

questions.question: Should team include this story in Sprint 4?

options.text: Yes, include it—5 points helps hit velocity target
No, story doesn't meet Definition of Ready—push to backlog refinement
Yes, but add placeholder tasks
Split story into smaller pieces during planning

feedback.correct: Story doesn't meet DoR (missing acceptance criteria, ingredients, specs). Including incomplete stories = mid-sprint delays, rework, failed commitments. Push to backlog refinement.
feedback.incorrect: DoR criteria: Clear acceptance criteria, sized/estimated, dependencies identified, team understands requirements. This story fails most criteria.

scenarios.title: Velocity-Based Capacity Planning
description: Carlos (GM): 'We need 40 points this sprint—critical deadline!'

questions.question: How many story points should team commit to?

options.text: 40 points (meet business need)
30 points (max from past sprints)
Average velocity ~28 points
25 points (conservative)

feedback.correct: Average velocity = (25+30+28+27)/4 = 28 points. Team commits to ~28 points, rejects Carlos's demand for 40 points (143% of capacity). Overcommitting leads to burnout and failed sprint goals.
feedback.incorrect: Velocity = average story points from past 3-5 sprints. (25+30+28+27)/4 = 27.5 ≈ 28 points. Sustainable pace wins.

scenarios.title: Sprint Backlog Flexibility
description: Carlos: 'If you finish early, can you add more features mid-sprint?'
Taylor: 'What if a story turns out more complex—can we remove it?'

questions.question: Can sprint backlog be modified during sprint?

options.text: No, sprint backlog is frozen once sprint starts
Yes, team can add/remove stories with PO collaboration, maintaining sprint goal
Yes, but only Scrum Master can approve changes
No, only add work if finished early, never remove

feedback.correct: Sprint backlog is flexible—team can add stories if finished early (with PO agreement), remove stories if complexity emerges (with PO collaboration). Sprint GOAL remains stable, sprint BACKLOG can flex.
feedback.incorrect: Sprint GOAL is stable, but sprint BACKLOG can be re-negotiated with PO. Agile is about adaptability, not rigid plans.

part1.name: WHAT to Build (PO + Team)
steps: Product Owner presents product backlog items (ordered by priority)
Team selects stories based on velocity (forecast)

content.productBacklog: Product Owner prioritizes (WHAT is most valuable?)
content.sprintBacklog: Development Team self-organizes (HOW to achieve sprint goal? Which tasks first?)
content.why: Cross-functional team knows technical dependencies, skills, capacity better than PO.

content.rule: If story doesn't meet DoR: Push to backlog refinement. Don't include incomplete stories.

content.definition: Velocity = Average story points from past 3-5 sprints
content.calculation: Sum past sprint points ÷ number of sprints = average velocity
content.commitment: Team forecasts work based on velocity, commits to sprint goal (NOT every story point)
content.warning: Overcommitting (40 points when velocity = 28) guarantees failure
content.pmbokRef: Agile Practice Guide page 64; PMBOK 7th Ed page 64

correct.text: This is Scrum's distributed authority—PO decides WHAT, team decides HOW. Development team self-organizes sprint backlog priorities based on technical dependencies.
Better to spend 30 minutes refining this story now than waste 2 days figuring it out mid-sprint. Stories must meet DoR before sprint inclusion.

screens.title: Multi-Team Sprint Coordination
screens.context: Savory launching mobile app (3 Scrum teams: Backend, Frontend, QA). Backend velocity: 32 points. Frontend velocity: 28 points. QA velocity: 20 points. Product Owner wants all 3 teams to commit to 40 points each for 'sprint alignment.'

questions.question: Should teams commit to 40 points each for alignment?

options.text: Yes, identical commitments ensure alignment
No, each team commits to own velocity (32, 28, 20). Coordinate goals, not identical points.

questions.question: What's the right approach for multi-team coordination?

options.text: Force identical story points across teams
Coordinate sprint goals and manage cross-team dependencies
Merge all teams into one large Scrum team

screens.title: Sprint Planning Mastery
screens.summary: Sprint Planning has two parts: WHAT (select stories based on velocity) + HOW (team self-organizes tasks). Team owns sprint backlog self-organization. DoR gates sprint inclusion. Velocity drives realistic forecasting.
takeaways: Two-part Sprint Planning: WHAT (PO + Team) + HOW (Team only)
Development Team self-organizes sprint backlog priorities (NOT PO, NOT SM)
Definition of Ready (DoR) gates sprint inclusion
Velocity = average story points from past 3-5 sprints
Sprint backlog flexible (add/remove with PO collaboration, maintaining sprint goal)

artifacts.title: Sprint Planning Checklist
artifacts.description: Two-part structure, DoR criteria, velocity calculation

characterClosing.text: We use velocity to forecast realistically, DoR to ensure stories are ready, and team self-organization for sprint backlog priorities. Sprint Planning done right = achievable sprint goals.
